questions.text: A 3900-g (8.6-lb) newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, he spontaneously cries, grimaces, and moves all four extremities. Over the next five minutes, he becomes cyanotic and tachypneic. Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is begun, but ten minutes after delivery the baby continues to appear cyanotic. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen bag-mask ventilation shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Breath sounds are normal on the right and absent on the left. Heart sounds are best heard in the right midclavicular line. The abdomen appears concave. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) is indicated in infants with CDH and respiratory failure who do not improve with mechanical ventilation, as well as those with persistent hypoxia and/or acidosis on conventional medical therapy. This patient's respiratory decompensation requires immediate treatment, which means that ECLS is not the most appropriate next step.

B) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal surfactant is indicated in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Neonates with NRDS may present with tachypnea and cyanosis, however, this patient's chest x-ray indicates CDH. While surfactant administration is also recommended in the management of CDH in infants born at < 34 weeks of gestation if the x-ray findings suggest concomitant NRDS, this patient was born at term and there is no evidence of NRDS on x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infant

The lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.

In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

This neonate has cyanosis, hypoxia, and tachypnea, which can be findings of congenital heart disease. Echocardiography can be used to confirm the presence of a cardiac malformation (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or transposition of the great vessels). However, this newborn's x-ray does not reveal any signs of heart disease (e.g., increased heart size or an abnormal configuration of the aortic arch), but rather findings indicating CDH.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical repair is indicated in all cases of CDH since spontaneous closure is unlikely and surgery may prevent further complications of the lung (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia and persistent pulmonary hypertension) and intestine (e.g., bowel obstruction, strangulation, or perforation). The most common procedure is the reduction of the hernial contents followed by closure (primary or using a biomaterial patch) of the diaphragmatic defect. However, surgery should be deferred until the newborn has been stabilized (most frequently at 24–48 hours); therefore, it is not the most appropriate next step in a patient with acute respiratory decompensation.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient has some of the characteristic features of tension pneumothorax, including respiratory distress, absent breath sounds over the affected side of the lung, and shifting of heart sounds to the contralateral side, suggesting mediastinal deviation. However, in addition to the mediastinal shift to the right, this patient's chest x-ray shows findings of CDH. While chest tube placement is the preferred and often life-saving treatment for pneumothorax, it is contraindicated in patients with a diaphragmatic hernia as there is a high risk of injury to the herniated bowel.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A large right tension pneumothorax is accompanied by lung collapse. When compared to the left hemithorax, no lung markings are seen in the right hemithorax beyond the margin of the collapsed right lung (green overlay). Signs of tension seen here include contralateral shift of mediastinal structures and depression of the right hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and arrow). Another sign that may be seen in tension pneumothorax is ipsilateral intercostal space widening.

An unrelated finding on this radiograph is slight curvature of the upper to midthoracic spine, convex to the left.

Black line and arrows: shift of mediastinal pleura; white line and arrows: shift of cardiomediastinal silhouette

F) CORRECT:

In patients with CDH, the compression of the lung from protruded abdominal contents may interfere with fetal lung maturation and lead to pulmonary hypoplasia, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and poor surfactant production, resulting in severe respiratory distress in the newborn. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the priority in all patients with CDH and should be performed before any further intervention because they help to decrease air swallowing and correct hypoxia. Bag-mask ventilation is contraindicated as air is pumped into the stomach and the bowel, resulting in gastric and/or intestinal distention and further compression of the lung. As in this patient, the majority (approximately 85%) of CDH cases are left-sided.

Following intubation, a nasogastric tube should be placed for gastric decompression to decompress the stomach/bowel and reduce lung compression.
questions.hint: This newborn exhibits respiratory distress (cyanosis, tachypnea), absent breath sounds on the left, heart sounds shifted further to the right, and a scaphoid abdomen. These features, together with the chest x-ray demonstrating a mediastinal shift to the right, bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax, confirm the diagnosis of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

questions.text: A 3900-g (8.6-lb) male infant is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated but a prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks showed a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Large bowel in the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane during fetal development can lead to congenital diaphragmatic hernia in the newborn. Because the liver protects the right hemidiaphragm, diaphragmatic hernias most commonly occur on the left side, resulting in displacement of the gastric fundus in the thorax. Congenital diaphragmatic hernias typically manifest with respiratory distress at birth, due to displacement of abdominal organs into the thorax and disruption of normal lung development (i.e., pulmonary hypoplasia).
Image Description:

Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.

Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

B) INCORRECT:

A ring of pancreatic tissue surrounding the duodenum is characteristic of an annular pancreas, which occurs due to impaired fusion of the ventral and dorsal bud of the pancreas during foregut rotation. The pleuroperitoneal membrane is not involved in pancreatic development.

C) INCORRECT:

Small and cystic kidneys are characteristic of multicystic dysplastic kidneys. Kidney development is not affected by the pleuroperitoneal membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy of the gastric pylorus is characteristic of pyloric stenosis, which typically manifests 2–6 weeks after birth with nonbilious, projectile vomiting. Risk factors for pyloric stenosis include smoking during pregnancy and macrolide use, but it is not associated with a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystic masses in the mediastinum are characteristic of bronchogenic cysts, which are caused by abnormal budding of the foregut during embryonic development. The pleuroperitoneal membranes are not involved in pulmonary development.

F) INCORRECT:

The presence of large bowel in the inguinal canal is characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia. Congenital inguinal hernias are caused by incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis and are not related to the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
questions.hint: Pulmonary hypoplasia is a common complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 3900-g (8-lb 11-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 27-year-old woman. Immediately after delivery, he develops cyanosis and tachypnea. He has not yet been fed. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows decreased breath sounds in the right lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows a sharply demarcated fluid-filled density in the right lung. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the x-ray findings?

choices.text: Abnormal budding of the ventral foregut
Fistula between the esophagus and the trachea

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bronchogenic cysts are typically unilocular cysts that arise during embryonic development. They are caused by abnormal budding of the foregut and subsequent dilation of the terminal or large bronchi. On chest x-ray, they appear as discrete, round, and sharply defined fluid-filled densities within the middle mediastinum or the pulmonary parenchyma. Bronchogenic cysts are often asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally in adults, but they can drain poorly, which causes airway compression with significant respiratory distress, as seen in this patient. Administering oxygen does not improve the patient's poor saturation, as the airway compression leads to the collapse of parts of the lung, which are subsequently not ventilated at all.

B) INCORRECT:

A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) can lead to involuntary aspiration of gastric acid or food and subsequent aspiration pneumonia. A patient with aspiration pneumonia would present with tachypnea, cyanosis, low oxygen saturation, and, possibly, fluid-filled regions due to lung abscess formation. However, symptoms are unlikely to manifest immediately after delivery and usually begin after the first feed.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased volume of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios) can result in pulmonary hypoplasia (Potter sequence), which would manifest with tachypnea, cyanosis, decreased oxygen saturation and decreased breath sounds. However, breath sounds would typically be decreased in not one but both lung fields in the case of Potter sequence and a chest x-ray would show opaque lung fields bilaterally, not a fluid-filled density. Moreover, other features of the Potter sequence such as craniofacial defects (e.g., flattened nose, low-set ears, retrognathia) and limb defects (e.g., club feet) would be present.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired fusion of the pleuroperitoneal membrane during embryonic development can cause congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Herniated bowel within the chest cavity can compress the lungs and cause tachypnea, cyanosis, and decreased oxygen saturation due to respiratory distress as well as decreased breath sounds. However, chest x-ray of a patient with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia would show parts of the bowel within the chest cavity. In addition, the majority of congenital diaphragmatic hernias occur on the left side, because the right hemidiaphragm is protected by the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

Alveolar surface tension is increased in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) as a result of surfactant deficiency. NRDS can cause tachypnea, cyanosis, decreased oxygen saturation, as well as decreased breath sounds. However, breath sounds would be decreased in not one but both lung fields and a chest x-ray would show a diffuse ground glass appearance on chest x-ray due to the collapsed alveoli, not a fluid-filled density. Moreover, NRDS typically occurs with preterm births; it would not be expected in this term infant.
Image Description:

X-ray chest of a premature infant
questions.hint: This newborn's decreased breath sounds and chest x-ray findings indicate a bronchogenic cyst, which occasionally causes airway obstruction and subsequent respiratory distress at birth with tachypnea, cyanosis, and hypoxemia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman reports 3 months of difficulty swallowing solid foods. She has no difficulty swallowing liquids and reports no odynophagia, dyspnea, or chest pain. She states that she has not had nausea, vomiting, or bowel changes.
CT of the chest is obtained (figure). When informed of the findings, the patient says that as a young child she was told she has a mass in her chest.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has had a mediastinal cystic structure since childhood. The most likely diagnosis is a bronchogenic cyst. Bronchogenic cysts arise from anomalous budding of the foregut during development and often do not become symptomatic until the second or third decade of life. On CT, bronchogenic cysts typically are sharply marginated with soft-tissue or water attenuation.

If the cyst is left untreated, risks include infection and impingement of surrounding structures. All symptomatic bronchogenic cysts should be considered for surgical removal.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management approach for a symptomatic bronchogenic cyst is surgical excision.

B) INCORRECT:

The structure shown on CT scan, as well as the chronicity, suggests that a malignant neoplasm is unlikely. Therefore, transbronchial needle biopsy, chemotherapy, and radiation would all be inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

If the cyst is left untreated, risks include infection and impingement of surrounding structures. All symptomatic bronchogenic cysts should be considered for surgical removal.

D) INCORRECT:

The structure shown on CT scan, as well as the chronicity, suggests that a malignant neoplasm is unlikely. Therefore, transbronchial needle biopsy, chemotherapy, and radiation would all be inappropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

The structure shown on CT scan, as well as the chronicity, suggests that a malignant neoplasm is unlikely. Therefore, transbronchial needle biopsy, chemotherapy, and radiation would all be inappropriate.

questions.text:
A late preterm male infant with limited prenatal care is being evaluated in the newborn nursery one hour after birth. He was born via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery without the presence of meconium-stained amniotic fluid. He underwent routine resuscitation in the delivery room, and his Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes of life, respectively. Shortly after birth, a nurse noted that he had increased work of breathing.
On examination, the infant has a temperature of 37.2°C, a heart rate of 175 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 82 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 78% while breathing ambient air. He has a caput succedaneum, nasal flaring, subcostal and intercostal retractions, grunting, and central cyanosis. His cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm without a murmur, and he has normal femoral pulses. He is notably tachypneic, and lung sounds are difficult to assess on the left. His abdomen is scaphoid in appearance.
A plain-film radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following features, if present, would be a positive prognostic feature in an infant with this condition?

choices.text: Arterial blood gas partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 80 mm Hg in the first 24 hours of life

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The majority of defects in infants with CDH occur on the left side, as seen in this patient. Right-sided defects occur in 10% to 15% of infants of CDH, and bilateral defects occur in 1% to 2%. Survival rates of infants with right- and left-sided defects appear to be similar. Bilateral defects, however, are associated with decreased likelihood of survival.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is in respiratory distress with asymmetric breath sounds and a chest radiograph that reveals abdominal contents in the left thoracic cavity. These findings are consistent with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), a condition that is typically (although not always) diagnosed prenatally. Infants who have a large defect in the diaphragm will develop symptoms of respiratory distress shortly after birth, whereas those with a small defect may go undiagnosed for months or even years.

CDH causes significant alterations to the pulmonary vasculature of both lungs, and almost all affected patients have a degree of pulmonary hypertension. Initial management of CDH includes intubation, mechanical ventilation, and decompression of the bowel with an oro- or nasogastric tube. These interventions reduce gaseous distention of the bowel, thereby improving oxygenation and ventilation of the lungs. Intubation and mechanical ventilation also allow for correction of respiratory acidosis and administration of oxygen and nitric oxide as pulmonary vasodilators for clinically significant pulmonary hypertension. Currently, the survival rate for infants born with CDH and cared for at tertiary-care centers ranges from 70% to 92% and is affected by multiple factors.

Herniation of the liver into the thoracic cavity with CDH is a poor prognostic factor associated with increased risk of morbidity and mortality. In fact, liver that does not herniate into the thoracic cavity is the most reliable prenatal predictor of postnatal survival.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a newborn with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and minimal breath sounds in the left lung field is congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

C) INCORRECT:

The majority of defects in infants with CDH occur on the left side, as seen in this patient. Right-sided defects occur in 10% to 15% of infants of CDH, and bilateral defects occur in 1% to 2%. Survival rates of infants with right- and left-sided defects appear to be similar. Bilateral defects, however, are associated with decreased likelihood of survival.

D) INCORRECT:

Prematurity (including late preterm birth between 34 and 36 6/7 weeks’ gestation) is a poor prognostic factor for survival in infants with CDH, with younger gestational ages associated with lower survival rates. In addition, infants born preterm with CDH are more likely to have associated chromosomal anomalies and cardiac defects than full-term infants, further affecting their survival.

E) INCORRECT:

An arterial blood gas partial pressure of carbon dioxide >60 mm Hg in the first 24 hours of life is suggestive of significant pulmonary hypoplasia and negatively affects survival. Similarly, preductal oxygen saturation levels that remain below 85% in the first 24 hours of life also suggest worse outcomes.

questions.text: A 3900-g (8.6-lb) male infant is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated but a prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks showed a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Large bowel in the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane during fetal development can lead to congenital diaphragmatic hernia in the newborn. Because the liver protects the right hemidiaphragm, diaphragmatic hernias most commonly occur on the left side, resulting in displacement of the gastric fundus in the thorax. Congenital diaphragmatic hernias typically manifest with respiratory distress at birth, due to displacement of abdominal organs into the thorax and disruption of normal lung development (i.e., pulmonary hypoplasia).
Image Description:

Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.

Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

B) INCORRECT:

A ring of pancreatic tissue surrounding the duodenum is characteristic of an annular pancreas, which occurs due to impaired fusion of the ventral and dorsal bud of the pancreas during foregut rotation. The pleuroperitoneal membrane is not involved in pancreatic development.

C) INCORRECT:

Small and cystic kidneys are characteristic of multicystic dysplastic kidneys. Kidney development is not affected by the pleuroperitoneal membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystic masses in the mediastinum are characteristic of bronchogenic cysts, which are caused by abnormal budding of the foregut during embryonic development. The pleuroperitoneal membranes are not involved in pulmonary development.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of large bowel in the inguinal canal is characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia. Congenital inguinal hernias are caused by incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis and are not related to the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
questions.hint: Pulmonary hypoplasia is a common complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen. A chest X-ray shows bowel loops in the left hemithorax. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In neonates with suspected congenital diaphragmatic hernia, decompression of the gastrointestinal tract is crucial. Bowel loops in the thorax compress the lungs, worsening respiratory distress. A nasogastric tube reduces intrathoracic pressure by evacuating air and secretions from the stomach and intestines, aiding in pulmonary expansion. This step is vital for preoperative stabilization, improving ventilation and minimizing complications during further management.

Key learning point: In infants with diaphragmatic hernia, the first step after stabilization is to insert a large nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach and intestines, reducing pressure on the lungs and improving ventilation.

B) INCORRECT:

Chest tube insertion is indicated for conditions like tension pneumothorax, not congenital diaphragmatic hernia. In this condition, abdominal contents herniate into the thorax, not air. Inserting a chest tube risks bowel injury, leading to perforation and infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical repair is not the first step. Initial management involves stabilizing respiratory status with intubation and nasogastric decompression. Surgery is performed after optimizing the patient's physiologic parameters to prevent further instability.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhaled nitric oxide treats pulmonary hypertension but does not address the mechanical lung compression from herniated abdominal contents in congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Initial management should focus on airway stabilization and gastrointestinal decompression.

questions.text: You have just delivered a male infant weighing 3900 g at 39 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. However, a prenatal ultrasound at 20 weeks showed a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane. Which one of the following findings is most likely to be seen on further evaluation of this patient?

choices.text: Large bowel in the inguinal canal.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small and cystic kidneys are characteristic of multicystic dysplastic kidneys. Kidney development is not affected by the pleuroperitoneal membrane.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic masses in the mediastinum are characteristic of bronchogenic cysts, which are caused by abnormal budding of the foregut during embryonic development. The pleuroperitoneal membranes are not involved in pulmonary development.

C) INCORRECT:

A ring of pancreatic tissue surrounding the duodenum is characteristic of an annular pancreas, which occurs due to impaired fusion of the ventral and dorsal bud of the pancreas during foregut rotation. The pleuroperitoneal membrane is not involved in pancreatic development.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of large bowel in the inguinal canal is characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia. Congenital inguinal hernias are caused by incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis and are not related to the pleuroperitoneal membrane.

E) CORRECT:

A defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane during fetal development can lead to congenital diaphragmatic hernia in the newborn. Because the liver protects the right hemidiaphragm, diaphragmatic hernias most commonly occur on the left side, resulting in displacement of the gastric fundus in the thorax. Congenital diaphragmatic hernias typically manifest with respiratory distress at birth, due to displacement of abdominal organs into the thorax and disruption of normal lung development (i.e., pulmonary hypoplasia).

Key learning point: A congenital diaphragmatic hernia results from a pleuroperitoneal membrane defect, allowing abdominal organs such as the gastric fundus to herniate into the thorax and impair lung development.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.

Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.
questions.hint: Pulmonary hypoplasia is a common complication of this patient's condition.
